newsitem.title: NEW ZEALAND: NZ dollar ends mid-range after quiet session.
newsitem.headline: NZ dollar ends mid-range after quiet session.

text.p: The New Zealand dollar ended around the middle of Thursday's range after a quiet session.
Comments from Australian Reserve Bank Governor Ian Macfarlane were perceived as meaning rates there would not go lower, which brought some selling of Kiwi against the Aussie.
But Kiwi ended little-changed at NZ$0.6842/49 from 0.6844/51 at the close, having traded a 0.6838-64 range on the day.
The Trade-Weighted Index closed at 67.85 from its 67.96 open, mostly reflecting a decline on the Australian dollar cross rate, which ended at A$0.8784/02.
A short squeeze early in the session took the Kiwi up to a high of 0.6864 where it met with offshore selling.
Dealers were generally bearish on the Kiwi but did not rule out another squeeze higher overnight.
"I think most people are in the bearish camp and for that reason they are a bit short," said one.
"But what tends to happen is that as the market moves up, the more people you get buying it on a stop loss basis."
He nevertheless expected weakness to re-emerge next week.
